description:
When I try to launch it, the following appears:
The following schema is missing
com.canonical.notify-osd
In order to work properly, Unity Tweak Tool recommends you install the necessary packages
If you see "we suggest you install all dependencies blabla", use "apt search" and install "notify-osd"; just as the error indicates: com.canonical.notify-osd, which is the missing dependency.
To use: open terminal and paste "sudo apt-get install notify-osd overlay-scrollbar".

description: Cool. Love it so much

...and if you do, here they are 
sudo apt-get install notify-osd
sudo apt-get install overlay-scrollbar

You can solve issues of missing "com.canonical.notify-osd" with the two commands as follows: 

1. Open a Terminal 
2. Execute: 

sudo apt-get install --reinstall notify-osd
sudo apt-get install --reinstall overlay-scrollbar

3. Re-execute Unit Tweak Tool

Have fun.
summary: It is awesome. Issues with missing "com.canonical.notify-osd"

description: sounded like an awesome tool, too - unfortunately have to rate it a 1 because it is broken in current-state.

(apt install notify-icons)
For the missing dependency error "com.canonical.notify-osd" run Synaptic and search for "notify-osd" then mark it to install. You're welcome.

description: missing dependencies

I get error that some conical package is missing. Searching what to do I found several tips on websites; none is working.
A generic problem with linux is that it copies bad things from Windows (like maximizing screen when dragged to the borders) and user interfaces are continuously changed every release. I develop software myself. We should not forget that swapping gas and clutch pedals would never be accepted in cars. Why do we continuously change user interface to hide the same problem elsewhere?

open your terminal, and enter the following

"sudo apt-get install unity-lens-applications"
"sudo apt-get install unity-lens-files"

that should do the trick.
If you are having more issues, I suggest using the "apt search" command followed by a key word such as "unity" and looking through the resulting list of available commands (although there are usually many) to find the one you are needing.

	unity-lens-files . Which the software installer does not give the exact name a generic name.
4. go to terminal
5. sudo apt-get install unity-lens-files
	note the actual package name is written. after install 
	type that and run.
	keep repeating the process till all packages are install and the sofware will load

To get it to work you must first do (credits to reviewer Jen): 
sudo apt install unity-lens-files
sudo apt install unity-lens-applications

Then, to actually run it: 
unity-tweak-tool

It still won't show up in Apps and you'll have to repeat the command every time, but at least you'll be able to use it.

The answer to installing lens apps is here

Partway down, it shows how to install the tweak tool:

sudo apt install unity-lens-applications
sudo apt install unity-lens-music
sudo apt install unity-lens-video
sudo apt install unity-lens-files
sudo apt install unity-lens-photos

In the past, it was the “Unity Tweak tool”; now it is “GNOME Tweak Tool”. GNOME tweak tool can be used for customization of the Ubuntu

Use this command and launch the "Tweak" application.

sudo apt-get install gnome-tweak-tool

type in terminal one by one:

sudo apt install unity-lens-applications
sudo apt install unity-lens-music
sudo apt install unity-lens-video
sudo apt install unity-lens-files
sudo apt install unity-lens-photos
sudo apt-get install unity-tweak-tool
unity-tweak-tool
where is it? should i use command to open it?

When I try to remove this broken app the installer says that it can't be removed. Save yourself the trouble and just do this in a terminal.

sudo apt-get update
sudo apt-get install unity-tweak-tool
